metadata.title: The effect of temperature and solid concentration on dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/MgO (20-80)-SAE50 hybrid nano-lubricant and proposing a new correlation: An experimental study

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
International Communications in Heat and Mass Transfer
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate / ichmt
The effect of temperature and solid concentration on dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/MgO (20–80)–SAE50 hybrid nano-lubricant and proposing a new correlation: An experimental study☆
Amin Asadi a,b,⁎, Meisam Asadi a,b,⁎, Mohammadhosein Rezaei c, Marzieh Siahmargoi c, Fahime Asadi c a Young researchers and Elite Club, Semnan Branch, Islamic Azad University, P. O. Box: 35196-97951, Semnan, Iran b Energy and Sustainable Development Research Center, Semnan Branch, Islamic Azad University, P. O. Box: 35196-97951, Semnan, Iran c Department of Mechanical Engineering, Semnan Branch, Islamic Azad University, P. O. Box: 35196-97951, Semnan, Iran
☆ Communicated by W.J. Minkowycz. ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Young Researchers and Eli Azad University, P. O. Box: 35196-97951, Semnan, Iran. E-mail addresses: Aminasadi64@gmail.com (A. Asadi) (M. Asadi), Mohamadhossin_rezaee@yahoo.com (M. Reza Marzieh.siahmargoii@hotmail.com (M. Siahmargoi), F.asa (F. Asadi).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.icheatmasstransfer.2016.08.02 0735-1933/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Available online 05 September 2016
The main objective of the present paper is to investigate the dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/MgO (20–80)–SAE50 hybrid nano-lubricant. The experiments carried out in solid concentrations ranging from0.25% to 2% and temperatures ranging from 25 °C to 50 °C. The results revealed that the nano-lubricant shows Newtonian behavior in all the studied temperatures and solid concentrations. Furthermore, the experimental results showed that the dynamic viscosity decreased as the temperature increased. It is also revealed that increasing the solid concentration leads to increasing the dynamic viscosity of the nano-lubricant in all the temperatures. Themaximum increase in dynamic viscosity took place at the solid concentration of 2% and temperature of 40 °C by 65% while the minimum increase was at the solid concentration of 0.25% and temperature of 25 °C by 14.4%. Finally, applying curve fitting method on the experimental data, a new model to predict the dynamic viscosity of the studied nano-lubricant in terms of temperature and solid concentration has been proposed.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Dynamic viscosity MWCNT MgO Solid concentration Temperature Nano-lubricant Correlation

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
A suspension of nano-size particles in conventional fluids, such as water, ethylene glycol, and oil, is called nanofluid. Since they possess high thermal conductivity and thermal performance in comparison with working fluids, they have grabbed the attention of many researchers in recent years [1–8]. From 1995 on which Choi [9], for the first time, introduced nanofluids, the applications of nanofluids have been widely developed in various thermal systems such as heat exchangers, heating and cooling engines, electronic devices, and so forth.
Undoubtedly, viscosity and thermal conductivity of nanofluids are two crucial factors which have direct effect on heat and mass transfer. In this ground, many researchers conducted various studies on thermal conductivity of nanofluid containing different nanoparticles (metal, metal oxide, and carbon nanotubes) [10–16]. Their results indicated that the thermal conductivity of nanofluids shows considerable
te Club, Semnan Branch, Islamic
, Meisamasadi91@gmail.com ei), di.teacher@gmail.com
1
enhancement by adding the nanoparticles and this enhancement results in improving the heat transfer rate. As for the viscosity of nanofluids, a considerable amount of literature has been published based on theoretical [17–20] and experimental studies [21–24]. Based on these studies, it can be concluded that many factors such as temperature, solid volume fraction, suspension techniques, particle size and shape, surfactant, type of nanoparticles, and base fluid has direct effect on the viscosity of nanofluids. On the other hand, many experimental papers have been published in recent years on a new class of nanofluids which called hybrid nanofluids [25–28]. Hybrid nanofluids are containing metallic and metal-oxide nanoparticles which can be able to improve the thermophysical properties of working fluids. Furthermore, hybrid nanofluids containing carbon nanotubes (CNTs), which has unique thermal properties, with metal-oxide nanoparticles have been considerably studied by researchers [29–31].
Since engine oils are used in various industrial and engineering applications, the crucial factor in energy saving would be improving the thermophysical properties of them. Moreover, many researchers have paid careful attention to rheological properties of them. In this regard, a new and innovative type of nanofluid called nano-lubricant (engine oil containing nanoparticles) has been introduced in recent years. Asadi and Asadi [32] have conducted an experimental study on rheological behavior of MWCNT/ZnO–engine oil nano-lubricant. Their results revealed that the dynamic viscosity of the nano-lubricant decreases as the temperature increases. They also proposed a new correlation to
predict the dynamic viscosity of the studied nano-lubricant. In another experimental investigation, Afrand et al. [33] studied the dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/SiO2-SAE40 nano-lubricant. They indicated that increasing the solid concentration leads to increasing the dynamic viscosity of the nano-lubricant. Hemmat et al. [34] experimentally investigated the effect of temperature and solid volume fraction on dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/SiO2(20–80)–SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricant. Furthermore, many experimental investigations on thermal and rheological properties of nanofluids with engine oil as the base fluid have been performed in recent years [35–38].
From what has been discussed above, it can be concluded that although the literature shows that a number of studies have been performed on rheological properties of nanofluids containing different type of nanoparticles, there are limited number of studies on rheological properties of engine oils. Furthermore, to the best of the authors' knowledge, there is no comprehensive study on the rheological properties of MWCNT/MgO–SAE50 hybrid nano-lubricant.
In the present investigation, the effect of temperature and solid concentration on rheological properties of MWCNT/MgO (20–80)–SAE50 hybrid nano-lubricant has been experimentally studied. The experiments carried out on different temperatures (ranging from 25 °C to 50 °C) and solid concentrations (ranging from 0.25% to 2%). Furthermore, based on the experimental measurements, a new correlation to predict the dynamic viscosity of the studied nano-lubricant in terms of temperature and solid concentration has been proposed.

sections.heading: 2. Sample preparation
sections.text:
In this investigation, applying two-step method, the MWCNT/MgO– engine oil (SAE50, Super Kian, Pars Oil Co., Iran) hybrid nano-lubricant has been prepared in six solid volume fractions (0.25%, 0.5%, 0.75%, 1%, 1.5%, and 2%) as the experimental sample. The MWCNT andMgO nanoparticles by the average diameter of 30 nm have been used by the ratio of 20 and 80%, respectively. Since the crucial step in this study is to disperse the nanoparticles into the base fluid uniformly and make a stable
nanofluid, a magnetic stirrer has been used for 2 h to succeed inmaking a stable nanofluid. Then, an ultrasonic processor (20 kHz, 1200 W, Topsonics, Iran) has been employed for 1 h so as to break down the probable agglomeration of the nanoparticles and making a superb dispersion. In this manner, a long-time stable nanofluid (at least 14 days) has been produced and no sedimentation has been observed by the naked eyes. Fig. 1 shows the TEM image of MWCNT andMgO nanoparticles. It can be seen that the average diameter of these nanoparticles are 30 nm.

sections.heading: 3. Viscosity measurement
sections.text: In this study, a Brookfield cone and plate viscometer (Brookfield engineering laboratories of the US, CAP2000+) has been employed to measure the viscosity of the nanofluid in solid concentrations ranging from 0.25% to 2% and temperatures ranging from 25 °C to 50 °C. The viscometer has been equipped with 2.4 cm 0.8° cone and the CPE-40 spindle. Moreover, the viscometer has been calibrated before the measurement with the base fluid (SAE50) at the ambient temperature. Table 1 presents the detailed information of the viscometer.

sections.heading: 4. Newtonian behavior
sections.text:
Many debates thus far have been made on the rheological behavior of nanofluids whether they are Newtonian or non-Newtonian fluids. For instance, Prasher et al. [39] have reported that the viscosity of a suspension containing Al2O3 is independent of shear rate while Kabelac andKuhnke [40] stated that the viscosity of such a suspension is directly affected by shear rate. Therefore, identifying whether the nanofluid is Newtonian or non-Newtonian must be the first step to investigate the rheological behavior of MWCNT/MgO–engine oil hybrid nanolubricant. The Newtonian behavior of nanofluids can be expressed as follows:
τ ¼ μγ ð1Þ
where τ, μ, and γ represent the shear stress, the dynamic viscosity, and the shear strain, respectively. The dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/MgO– engine oil hybrid nano-lubricant with respect to shear rate and temperature at the solid concentration of 0.75% has been shown in Fig. 2. Based on this figure, it can be concluded that under the conditions of the present investigation, the studied nanofluid shows Newtonian behavior.

sections.heading: 5. Dynamic viscosity in different temperatures and solid concentrations
sections.text:
Fig. 3 (A) shows the dynamic viscosity of MWCNT/MgO–engine oil hybrid nano-lubricant with respect to temperature in different solid concentrations. As can be seen, increasing the temperature leads to decreasing the dynamic viscosity of the studied nano-lubricant in all solid concentrations. It can be interesting to note that in a constant
temperature, increasing the solid concentration results in increasing the dynamic viscosity of the nanofluid. This increase is more significant in lower temperatures compared to the higher ones. The dynamic viscosity of the studied nano-lubricant with respect to solid concentration in different temperatures has been displayed in Fig. 3 (B).
Fig. 4 reveals the variation of viscosity enhancement with respect to temperature in different solid concentrations. It can be clearly seen that the maximum increase in viscosity in solid concentrations of 0.75%, 1%, 1.5%, and 2% was at the temperature of 40 °C while in solid concentrations of 0.25% and 0.5%, the maximum increase took place at the temperature of 35 °C. On the other hand, the maximum increase in dynamic viscosity was at the solid concentration of 2% and temperature of 40 °C by 65%while theminimum increase was at the solid concentration of 0.25% and temperature of 25 °C by 14.4%. It is also interesting to note that increase in dynamic viscosity of the studied nano-lubricant at solid concentration of 0.25% and temperatures of 25, 35, 45, and 55 °C
concentrations, and (B) solid concentration in different temperatures.
was less than 20%which can be assumed as a positive point in industrial and engineering application of this nano-lubricantwhere pressure drop and pumping power are important. It is interesting to note that theminimum and maximum enhancement in the dynamic viscosity was 2.7% and 80%, respectively, which occurred at the temperature of 25 °C and 50 °C and solid concentrations of 0.25% and 2%, respectively. On the other hand, the maximum reduction in dynamic viscosity of the nanolubricant, by increasing the temperature in each solid concentration, was approximately 77%. This value was more or less similar in all the studied solid concentrations.

sections.heading: 6. Comparison between theoretical model and experimental data
sections.text:
Various theoretical models to predict the dynamic viscosity of nanofluid have been proposed by researchers thus far. In the present study, three commonly used models, Einstein [41], Batchelor [18], and Wang [42], have been selected to examine their capability to predict thedynamic viscosity of the studied nanofluid and compare their results with the experimental data. Table 2 displays the selected theoretical models.
The comparison between the selected theoreticalmodels and experimental data has been displayed in Fig. 5. It is crystal clear that neither of these models are able to predict the dynamic viscosity of the nanofluid in precise manner. Thus, it can be concluded that it is necessary to
propose a model which is able to predict the dynamic viscosity of the nanofluid in acceptable range of accuracy.

sections.heading: 7. Proposed correlation
sections.text:
In the present investigation, by themeans of curve fittingmethod on the experimental data, a new model to predict the dynamic viscosity (μnf) of MWCNT/MgO–engine oil hybrid nano-lubricant in terms of solid concentration (φ) and temperature (T) has been proposed as follows:
μnf ¼ 328201 T−2:053 φ0:09359 ð2Þ
Fig. 6 demonstrates a comparison made between the output of the proposed model and experimental data. As can be seen, the outputs of the proposed model are in excellent correspondence with the experimental data in all the studied temperatures and solid concentrations. It is interesting to note that the maximum error of the proposed model is approximately 8% (Fig. 7), which shows the excellent ability of the proposed model to predict the dynamic viscosity of the studied nanofluid. Thus it can be concluded that the proposed model is able to predict the dynamic viscosity of the studied nano-lubricant in the range of the studied temperatures (°C) and solid concentrations precisely.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusion
sections.text:
In the present study, the dynamic viscosity of the MWCNT/MgO– engine oil hybrid nano-lubricant in different solid concentrations ranging from 0.25% to 2% and temperatures ranging from 25 °C to 50 °C has been experimentally investigated. In addition, applying curve fitting method on the experimental data, a new model to predict the dynamic viscosity of the studied nanofluid in terms of temperature and solid concentration has been proposed.
Based on the experimental results, the following can be concluded:
• The nano-lubricant showed Newtonian behavior in all the studied temperatures and solid concentrations. • In all the studied solid concentrations, dynamic viscosity of the nanolubricant decreased as the temperature increased. • In all the studied temperatures, dynamic viscosity of the nanolubricant increased as the solid concentration increased. • The temperature of 35 °C can be called critical temperatures in which the maximum dynamic viscosity enhancement in solid concentration of 0.25% and 0.5% takes place while for the rest of the studied solid concentrations, the temperature of 40 °C is the critical temperature in which the maximum dynamic viscosity enhancement takes place. • The minimum increase in dynamic viscosity of the studied nanolubricant was at the temperature of 25 °C and solid concentration of 0.25% by 14.4% while the maximum increase was at the temperature of 40 °C and solid concentration of 2% by 65%. • Applying the curve fittingmethod on experimental data, a newmodel to predict the dynamic viscosity of the studied nano-lubricant in terms of temperature and solid concentration has been proposed. The maximum error of the proposed model is just under 8%.

sections.heading: Acknowledgment
sections.text: The authorswould like to express their sincere gratitude to Professor Mohammad Hemmat Esfe and Mr. Hadi Rostamian for their invaluable advice and guidance throughout the present project.
